awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG: Leveraging community partnerships and intelligent technologies to address septic system water quality risks in the Flathead Basin
awd_abstract_narration:
Aging and poorly maintained septic systems can contribute to degradation in water quality through supply of nutrients and pathogenic microorganisms. However, as non-point sources of pollution, septic-derived wastes receive poor regulatory oversight. Septic system maintenance and eventual replacement is entirely reliant on individual homeowners. In the state of Montana, nearly half of all homes utilize septic systems for wastewater disposal. The combination of expanding populations, with dispersed development, and hence increased dependence on septic systems, together with weak regulatory enforcement, has high potential to lead to increased septic-derived degradation of surface waters and groundwaters across the state. The harnessing of smart technologies, including real-time data collection, transmission, and automated data analysis, may provide a novel opportunity for engaging homeowners in septic system best practices.  This project will engage active stakeholder groups in the Flathead Basin, including the Flathead Basin Commission, a state-legislated organization; nonprofit water protection groups; and state and federal agencies. By forging new collaborations between natural and social scientists and the basin-wide community, the project will identify data-driven solutions to a growing problem specific to lake water quality.

This project will engage a local stakeholder network, building on their work to date to address septic systems as a non-point source of pollution to Flathead Lake in northwest Montana. Specific planned activities as part of the project include: (a) co-host a 3-day workshop of local and basin stakeholders to identify gaps in research, knowledge, and expertise; (b) proof-of-concept on the use of real-time data to motivate homeowners to adopt septic system best management practices; (c) pilot a shoreline monitoring approach using a combination of remote sensing and microbial source tracking technologies to identify lakeshore areas receiving poorly treated septic leachate; and (d) assess policies and governance frameworks, including incentives and financing solutions, that work to mitigate the risks from failing septic systems to public health and surface water and groundwater contamination. This project's interdisciplinary approach combines efforts to understand environmental responses, potential behavioral responses of homeowners, and possible policy and governance responses to the septic issue, which is a first step to resolving knowledge gaps that prevent identifying solutions. Outcomes from our activities will inform a subsequent effort to advance data and research infrastructure in geospatial and socio-hydrological sciences, with specific focus on strategies for developing a smart and connected basin community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For decades, the US Environmental Protection Agency has promoted septic systems as a cost-effective and long-term solution for meeting public health and water quality goals (EPA, 1997). However, old, poorly maintained, and/or improperly sited septic systems discharge inadequately treated sewage that threatens water resources (Withers et al., 2014). Potential threats from underperforming septic systems include fecal contamination, nitrate enrichment of drinking water sources, disease outbreaks, and surface waters overly enriched in nutrients leading to excessive growth of algae that degrade aesthetics and recreational amenities (Diaz-Elsayed et al., 2017; Withers et al., 2014).

Septic systems are regulated by state, Tribal, and county governments.  Typically, local county health departments approve septic design and issue installation permits. With few exceptions, once installed, there is no further oversight of the system. Homeowners are responsible for the care and maintenance of their septic and thus the efficacy of the system to treat household sewage. 

In Montana, 50% of households rely on septic (DEQ, 2018). In 2020, >1500 kms of rivers and 145 km2 of lakes were listed as impaired because of septic pollution (DEQ, 2021). The Flathead Lake watershed in northwest Montana, the geographic region of our project, is widely known for its crystal clear and clean water.  Development pressure is precipitously changing the watershed while perpetuating a heavy reliance on septic systems. The combination of new, dispersed development in un-sewered areas; aging infrastructure; anemic oversight; and the failure of homeowners to adopt best maintenance practices portends a worsening in surface water and groundwater impairment from septic systems. 

To address septic risks to water quality, our project employed an interdisciplinary approach to understand environmental responses, potential behavioral responses of homeowners, and possible policy responses.

Our project commenced with a 2-day workshop co-hosted with the Flathead Basin Commission, a legislated entity tasked with protecting the high-quality waters of the basin. We invited a diverse array of experts to review the current understanding of septic-related water issues, summarize policies and programs addressing wastewater-related risks, and facilitate broader communication among engaged parties. Workshop participants agreed on the need to better understand, quantify, and share the magnitude of the septic issue in order to mobilize the public to act.  The workshop coalesced around multi-pronged solutions that include promoting centralized systems; replacing, upgrading, and maintaining existing septic systems; and incorporating cutting-edge waste management technologies.  Outputs from the workshop culminated in a 2022 "Septic Roadshow," spearheaded by Flathead Basin Commission, that traveled throughout the watershed to speak with county commissioners, Tribal authorities, health departments, and planners. A representative of the Montana State Legislature, a workshop participant, subsequently introduced legislation to fund a state-wide septic system database. Although this policy effort was unsuccessful, it demonstrates the growing recognition that solutions to septic pollution require concerted efforts directed toward data accessibility.

To evaluate the changes to nearshore lake environments from septic inputs, we developed and piloted a shoreline monitoring approach. We sampled groundwater seeps for nutrients and fecal microorganisms.  Although elevated nutrient concentrations were detected, there was no clear evidence that these nutrients stemmed from septic systems. Next, we sampled nearshore lake waters for the presence of pharmaceuticals and personal care products, chemical contaminants associated with septic pollution, and algae for the presence of septic-derived nutrients. The samples provided compelling evidence of septic inputs to the lake. These preliminary results provided critical information on approaches and methods suitable for monitoring septic pollution in Flathead Lake.

An essential element in addressing septic pollution is inspiring homeowners to protect the common pool water resources of the basin. We asked a small group of homeowners to reveal their readiness to replace their septic systems, along with the attendant motivational factors that would influence their decision-making. Homeowners revealed a greater readiness to replace their septic in the next 6-30 years compared to the next 5 years. Homeowner readiness was positively associated with year-round residency, lower costs, and ability to replace. Importantly, homeowners wanted data on how their septic systems were degrading water quality.

Our investigation of policy responses to septic pollution involved a case study of Seely Lake, Montana, where contamination of groundwaters has been linked to septic systems. A centralized sewer system was advanced as a solution by county authorities; however, citizens twice rejected ballot initiatives to fund a centralized sewer system. A qualitative analysis of local newspaper coverage identified common themes contributing to perceived risk factors. Forefront in citizens' minds were cost, misinformation, and subsequent growth associated with sewering. Trust and miscommunication between the public and experts were also factors influencing perceived risks.

Funds from this planning grant supported two graduate students at the University of Montana. A master's student in Resource Conservation undertook the case study of Seeley Lake and published a thesis. A second master's student in the School of Journalism published 2 news media articles and a professional paper.
